AMP Story.1112.What do you need to know when scaling up your business?

parameterValues.DE:Objective:
We have then proposed the below synopsis and the talent list who will answer the question: What do you need to know when scaling up your business?

The first slide would feature 3 x stats on how many people find it difficult to grow a business and why, setting the scene.
The next 4 or 5 x slides would each feature one of the talents - a headshot, and then a key takeaway from their answer to the question. The question will be at the top of each slide, and their nugget of info at the bottom.
The final slide will drive to the Amex hub.

Our proposed talent list is below and we're waiting to hear back on their availability:
Lynne Franks, businesswomen and founder of SEED
Emma Sinclair, Enterprise Nation
Ishaan Malhi, Trussle founder (first UK online mortgage brokerage)
Tessa Clarke, Olio co-founder (combats food waste)
Ben Jeffries, founder of Influencer (has clients like Apple, Alibaba and McDonalds)
Guy Riese, founded his first business aged 13 and now runs UpLearn, which reinvents tutoring and help those whose education has been affected by illness through the use of AI and cognitive science

ADV.FP.DB.1609 - Moju Drinks

parameterValues.DE:Brief:
Option 2 - Richard Goldsmith only - APPROVED SYNOPSIS

This article would be more of a Moju case study, and would focus on telling the story of the brand and the importance of wellness in particular.
We’ll open the article with copy around the booming wellness scene and the explosion of products such as healthy snacks and juices, setting the scene to tell the story of Moju - which we will explain came from Richard and Charlie’s desire to combat the stress of their jobs by creating juices that ensured they got their nutrients in the simplest way possible.


We’ll feature comment from HR and workplace wellness experts on the importance of business owners and entrepreneurs staying healthy, and the best ways they can do this, and then go on to tell the story of Moju, up to the present day. Throughout the copy we will use quotes from the interview with Richard to look at how he manages his work-life balance, with copy on ‘intentionalised time’ and the wellness perks Moju offers its staff.


We will have a box out on 5 simple life hacks to work wellness into your busy work life, including scheduling in time to exercise/see friends, using mindfulness apps for quick meditation sessions, giving your employees free time/money to pursue their passions etc.
We will also include a box out on healthy lunch/breakfast/snack ideas from a nutritionist to ensure business owners stay well-fuelled and healthy. 
Throughout the copy we will feature roundels of stats around business owner stress as well as stats on the most popular ways CEOs achieve balance.

Note from Pedro: A quick one to flag out ahead of the develop concept, that the level of complexity on our AMP stories needs to be reduced. 
We are moving away form Google guidelines on their product and is causing issues on various devices as they only support the 2 latest versions of Desktop browsers and Android mobile devices. iOS devices only support Chrome browser and no Safari

Amp devs forward me this page, they have some visual mini samples there but it is mostly to avoid adding layers of animation and sticking to the constrains of the template.. https://github.com/ampproject/amphtml/blob/master/extensions/amp-story/amp-story.md#migrating-from-01-to-10

parameterValues.DE:Objective:
The future of mobility – the rise in automated and electric vehicles, mobility as a service, e.g. Uber, Zip Cars – Mobility trends report due out in March, so as early as possible after that (subject to 10 week lead time?)

This will open by setting the scene of the new mobility ecosystem by creating a comic strip of someone ordering an Uber/Zipcar/Via Van home after a holiday, getting picked up in an electric carpool vehicle, ordering dinner home from someone who delivers it on a motorcycle etc. Demonstrating the reach of the new mobility.

The body copy will explain all the new developments - autonomous vehicles, personalised transport, the role of data in all this, impact on the automotive industry, Mobility as a service programmes etc.

Flowing into a timeline showing the history of mobility/transport in the UK, from the first car in 1892 right through to uber and electric cars now. Then splitting into sections: 

Automated vehicles and where they’re set to go next, as well as the implications for insurers, legal firms and other professional services businesses. An annotated illo of a driverless vehicle showing the cool new whizzy features they’ll have and in which UK business sectors they can make the most impact 

Mobility as a service - an infographic explaining what it is (an intermodal journey planner providing combinations of different transport modes: car-sharing, car rental, underground, rail, bus, bike-sharing, taxi, etc that operates in real-time; a single payment portal like that for smartphones, whereby users can pay as they go or else buy a ‘service bundle’ in advance; a booking system incorporating the entire end-to-end journey stages), as well as exploring the major players in this space and where it’s set to go next, as well as the role of data in MaaS. We’ll also explore why brands like Uber and Lyft have flourished, and the challenges for these businesses (data protection, user privacy, cost)

CONTINUES IN CONTENT BOX BELOW
parameterValues.DE:Call to Action: Tracked url https://ad.doubleclick.net/ddm/trackclk/N8083.124621MSNUK/B22370404.240723500;dc_trk_aid=450325758;dc_trk_cid=105350124;dc_lat=;dc_rdid=;tag_for_child_directed_treatment=;tfua=
parameterValues.DE:Content:
CONTINUED

Sustainable mobility and the rise of hybrid and electric vehicles, including an infographic showing the benefits and challenges of businesses using electric vehicles (cost, CSR reputation etc) as well as copy on where electric mobility will go next, including expert commentary

Final section will look at the UK’s mobility disrupters - new brands and businesses across the themes discussed throughout that will be shaking up and revolutionising the sector, including quotes from these brands and headshots and company info in a small infographic.

There will be roundels throughout with relevant stats and figures.

L-D&DB.LONGFORM.2806.5G Workforce

parameterValues.DE:Objective:
Future consumer trends
The future of mobility (car ownership at an all time low – take a different angle to deep dive report above into mobility, to cover other millennial trends), overnight trends such as the popularity of veganism, data security and consumer trust etc. What could Mid Corporates learn from Millennials? May/June if possible
parameterValues.DE:Call to Action: Tracked link https://ad.doubleclick.net/ddm/trackclk/N8083.124621MSNUK/B22370404.240723500;dc_trk_aid=443465905;dc_trk_cid=105350124;dc_lat=;dc_rdid=;tag_for_child_directed_treatment=;tfua=
parameterValues.DE:Content:
What can businesses learn from Millennials?

This longform will open with a tongue-in-cheek look at current attitudes towards Millennials (over-sensitive snowflakes, spend all their money on avocado toast, always taking Insta selfies) - and then we’ll bust these stereotypes (Millennials are very digital-savvy, emotionally intelligent etc) and ask what can business leaders learn from them?

We’ll do an infographic of the key attributes of Millennials such as being collaborative, digitally savvy, pro-sustainability (environmentally aware, socially responsible etc), flexible workers and self-starters. We can do this as an annotated illustration of a Millennial, with copy like ‘Self-starters….which means they’re effective at working from home, coming up with creative solutions to problems’ - basically what they are and what this can bring to businesses.

The next section of body copy will explore why businesses need to look to new sources for inspiration - such as keeping up with digital disruptor competitors, global expansion, economic uncertainty, attracting and retaining talent. We’ll include pull stats and roundels here, and explore these challenges in greater depth with expert comment.

The next section will look at future consumer and millennial trends, and how businesses can piggyback on these and use them to their advantage. We’ll include a box out from an expert trend spotter giving their view on what mid-market businesses can learn from trends, both in general (it’s good to be innovative) and specifically now (rise of digital etc means markets change more quickly than ever and agility is key, for example).

CONTINUED BELOW
parameterValues.DE:Any other relevant information:
CONTINUED

We’ll have some body copy, and then an infographic looking at the top 8 consumer trends for the next 12 months (mobility and the sharing culture, social responsibility including veganism and recycling, taking back the data privacy power and protecting our information more, valuing experiences over material goods and so on). We’ll include tips on why and how business leaders should capitalise on these trends in the infographic, and expand on this in the body copy.

We’ll do box outs on the major trends as selected by Natwest (mobility as a service, veganism, data protection) and get experts to comment on how mid-corp business leaders can make the most of these.

Finally we’ll include copy on what business leaders can learn from one of the biggest millennial and consumer trends of all - focusing on making a difference to the greater good and not just making money. These characteristics have contributed to an exciting and promising new business trend: social entrepreneurship. From poverty to conservation to STEM funding, the world is filled with problems, and social entrepreneurship aims to use commerce to solve them. Business owners can add meaning to their entrepreneurial pursuits by incorporating elements of social entrepreneurship into their business models. Partnering with a charity, donating man-hours and participating in revenue-sharing arrangements.

OOA.1208.Cyber crime

parameterValues.DE:Objective:
Topic:  Cyber Security

Editorial angle/focus:
In our recent NatWest research into mid market companies, for our ‘view from the boardroom’ report, Cyber Security was found to be one of the top four priorities/concerns for mid market companies.  We would like to produce an insightful article that guides them through the key things to think about, should the (probably) inevitable happen – and provide practical advice and steps on the key actions to take and key things to think about, after a cyber security breach/attempt – and pre-emptive actions to take, before such an event occurs:


Being prepared for the inevitable and who can really help when it's gone REALLY wrong.  What do you really need from a digital forensic company, what are the questions to ask them? What do you really need from a PR company, what do you advise suppliers, clients, shareholders etc?

N.B.:  although we want to highlight the seriousness of this topic, we don’t want to scaremonger, but provide practical advise and empower customers.

See article linked here for more background and the bank’s perspective:
https://intranet.rbsres01.net/sites/comms-hub/cpb/Pages/cyber-security-conference.aspx

 
Potential contributors (both quoted in the above article):
Tim Rowlins, Director, NCC Group
Chris Ulliot, Chief Information Security Officer for the RBS Group – spoke alongside Alison Rose at a recent cyber security customer event
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    
If you would like access to Chris Ulliot, or Tim Rowlins (who is Chris’ contact), then please check in with Mandy at NatWest– she is dealing with Silas Bartlett in the security team, to organise having Chris Ulliot on the Piers Linney/Cyber Security filmed panel – so she can help you to co ordinate so that both asks are aligned.

L-D&DB.LONGFORM.2905.Sustainability

parameterValues.DE:Objective: Sustainability – what’s coming down the track for companies to think about – latest trends in consumer ethics, impacts of sustainability challenges on a company’s supply chain etc – April/May – subject to editorial lead time
parameterValues.DE:Content:
This long form will open with copy around the importance of sustainability (environmental, social, charity work) for UK businesses, including a stats cloud/infographic showing how many businesses have CSR policies, increases in sustainable business over the past decade and what types of sustainable actions businesses do (recycling, charity work etc)
This will following into background on why we need to be more sustainable - more of a macro economic overview, with expert comment. We'll also look at the consumer trend toward being more ethical (veganism, environmentally conscious, socially responsible etc) and include the top 8 sustainability trends that are impacting businesses
The main section will be an infographic of the ideal sustainable business, so an illustration of an office, annotated to show all the ways in which they can be sustainable - Sustainable mobility and the rise of hybrid and electric fleets, recycling, eco-friendly office supplies, charity days out, community work, etc. , including an infographic showing the benefits and challenges of businesses using electric vehicles (cost, CSR reputation etc)
The next section will look at the barriers to UK plc becoming more sustainable such as: cost to businesses; lack of government support in terms of ideas on how companies can become more sustainable and reduce emissions; lack of available information around funding; how to incentivise staff; we’ll also explore how businesses can overcome these challenges, such as by forming partnerships with other businesses with areas of common interest who are committed to making a difference - like making greener supply chain choices and choosing sustainable partners and suppliers. 
This will continue into a ‘looking to the future’ section where we’ll speak to sustainability experts about what the future looks like for businesses aiming to be more sustainable, and tips on what they can do to stay ahead of the crowd

CONTINUED BELOW
parameterValues.DE:Any other relevant information:
CONTINUED

The last section will look at 5 businesses that are already putting sustainability first, including NatWest. For example, Dell is working with clean ocean company Lonely Whale to fight plastics pollution, and HP’s Instant Ink service combines technology, customer service and environmental responsibility, by delivering replacement ink cartridges to customers when their printer detects low ink levels. We’ll include expert quotes and comment from these companies in here too

L-D&DB.LONGFORM.1811.Digitisation

parameterValues.DE:Objective:
The future of mobility – the rise in automated and electric vehicles, mobility as a service, e.g. Uber, Zip Cars – Mobility trends report due out in March, so as early as possible after that (subject to 10 week lead time?)

This will open by setting the scene of the new mobility ecosystem by creating a comic strip of someone ordering an Uber/Zipcar/Via Van home after a holiday, getting picked up in an electric carpool vehicle, ordering dinner home from someone who delivers it on a motorcycle etc. Demonstrating the reach of the new mobility.

The body copy will explain all the new developments - autonomous vehicles, personalised transport, the role of data in all this, impact on the automotive industry, Mobility as a service programmes etc.

Flowing into a timeline showing the history of mobility/transport in the UK, from the first car in 1892 right through to uber and electric cars now. Then splitting into sections: 

Automated vehicles and where they’re set to go next, as well as the implications for insurers, legal firms and other professional services businesses. An annotated illo of a driverless vehicle showing the cool new whizzy features they’ll have and in which UK business sectors they can make the most impact 

Mobility as a service - an infographic explaining what it is (an intermodal journey planner providing combinations of different transport modes: car-sharing, car rental, underground, rail, bus, bike-sharing, taxi, etc that operates in real-time; a single payment portal like that for smartphones, whereby users can pay as they go or else buy a ‘service bundle’ in advance; a booking system incorporating the entire end-to-end journey stages), as well as exploring the major players in this space and where it’s set to go next, as well as the role of data in MaaS. We’ll also explore why brands like Uber and Lyft have flourished, and the challenges for these businesses (data protection, user privacy, cost)

CONTINUES IN CONTENT BOX BELOW

parameterValues.DE:Objective:
Future consumer trends
The future of mobility (car ownership at an all time low – take a different angle to deep dive report above into mobility, to cover other millennial trends), overnight trends such as the popularity of veganism, data security and consumer trust etc. What could Mid Corporates learn from Millennials? May/June if possible
parameterValues.DE:Call to Action: Tracked link https://ad.doubleclick.net/ddm/trackclk/N8083.124621MSNUK/B22370404.240723500;dc_trk_aid=443465905;dc_trk_cid=105350124;dc_lat=;dc_rdid=;tag_for_child_directed_treatment=;tfua=
parameterValues.DE:Content:
What can businesses learn from Millennials?

This longform will open with a tongue-in-cheek look at current attitudes towards Millennials (over-sensitive snowflakes, spend all their money on avocado toast, always taking Insta selfies) - and then we’ll bust these stereotypes (Millennials are very digital-savvy, emotionally intelligent etc) and ask what can business leaders learn from them?

We’ll do an infographic of the key attributes of Millennials such as being collaborative, digitally savvy, pro-sustainability (environmentally aware, socially responsible etc), flexible workers and self-starters. We can do this as an annotated illustration of a Millennial, with copy like ‘Self-starters….which means they’re effective at working from home, coming up with creative solutions to problems’ - basically what they are and what this can bring to businesses.

The next section of body copy will explore why businesses need to look to new sources for inspiration - such as keeping up with digital disruptor competitors, global expansion, economic uncertainty, attracting and retaining talent. We’ll include pull stats and roundels here, and explore these challenges in greater depth with expert comment.

The next section will look at future consumer and millennial trends, and how businesses can piggyback on these and use them to their advantage. We’ll include a box out from an expert trend spotter giving their view on what mid-market businesses can learn from trends, both in general (it’s good to be innovative) and specifically now (rise of digital etc means markets change more quickly than ever and agility is key, for example).

CONTINUED BELOW
parameterValues.DE:Any other relevant information:
CONTINUED

We’ll have some body copy, and then an infographic looking at the top 8 consumer trends for the next 12 months (mobility and the sharing culture, social responsibility including veganism and recycling, taking back the data privacy power and protecting our information more, valuing experiences over material goods and so on). We’ll include tips on why and how business leaders should capitalise on these trends in the infographic, and expand on this in the body copy.

We’ll do box outs on the major trends as selected by Natwest (mobility as a service, veganism, data protection) and get experts to comment on how mid-corp business leaders can make the most of these.

Finally we’ll include copy on what business leaders can learn from one of the biggest millennial and consumer trends of all - focusing on making a difference to the greater good and not just making money. These characteristics have contributed to an exciting and promising new business trend: social entrepreneurship. From poverty to conservation to STEM funding, the world is filled with problems, and social entrepreneurship aims to use commerce to solve them. Business owners can add meaning to their entrepreneurial pursuits by incorporating elements of social entrepreneurship into their business models. Partnering with a charity, donating man-hours and participating in revenue-sharing arrangements.

OOA.1208.Cyber crime

parameterValues.DE:Objective:
Topic:  Cyber Security

Editorial angle/focus:
In our recent NatWest research into mid market companies, for our ‘view from the boardroom’ report, Cyber Security was found to be one of the top four priorities/concerns for mid market companies.  We would like to produce an insightful article that guides them through the key things to think about, should the (probably) inevitable happen – and provide practical advice and steps on the key actions to take and key things to think about, after a cyber security breach/attempt – and pre-emptive actions to take, before such an event occurs:


Being prepared for the inevitable and who can really help when it's gone REALLY wrong.  What do you really need from a digital forensic company, what are the questions to ask them? What do you really need from a PR company, what do you advise suppliers, clients, shareholders etc?

N.B.:  although we want to highlight the seriousness of this topic, we don’t want to scaremonger, but provide practical advise and empower customers.

See article linked here for more background and the bank’s perspective:
https://intranet.rbsres01.net/sites/comms-hub/cpb/Pages/cyber-security-conference.aspx

 
Potential contributors (both quoted in the above article):
Tim Rowlins, Director, NCC Group
Chris Ulliot, Chief Information Security Officer for the RBS Group – spoke alongside Alison Rose at a recent cyber security customer event
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    
If you would like access to Chris Ulliot, or Tim Rowlins (who is Chris’ contact), then please check in with Mandy at NatWest– she is dealing with Silas Bartlett in the security team, to organise having Chris Ulliot on the Piers Linney/Cyber Security filmed panel – so she can help you to co ordinate so that both asks are aligned.

L-D&DB.LONGFORM.2905.Sustainability

parameterValues.DE:Objective: Sustainability – what’s coming down the track for companies to think about – latest trends in consumer ethics, impacts of sustainability challenges on a company’s supply chain etc – April/May – subject to editorial lead time
parameterValues.DE:Content:
This long form will open with copy around the importance of sustainability (environmental, social, charity work) for UK businesses, including a stats cloud/infographic showing how many businesses have CSR policies, increases in sustainable business over the past decade and what types of sustainable actions businesses do (recycling, charity work etc)
This will following into background on why we need to be more sustainable - more of a macro economic overview, with expert comment. We'll also look at the consumer trend toward being more ethical (veganism, environmentally conscious, socially responsible etc) and include the top 8 sustainability trends that are impacting businesses
The main section will be an infographic of the ideal sustainable business, so an illustration of an office, annotated to show all the ways in which they can be sustainable - Sustainable mobility and the rise of hybrid and electric fleets, recycling, eco-friendly office supplies, charity days out, community work, etc. , including an infographic showing the benefits and challenges of businesses using electric vehicles (cost, CSR reputation etc)
The next section will look at the barriers to UK plc becoming more sustainable such as: cost to businesses; lack of government support in terms of ideas on how companies can become more sustainable and reduce emissions; lack of available information around funding; how to incentivise staff; we’ll also explore how businesses can overcome these challenges, such as by forming partnerships with other businesses with areas of common interest who are committed to making a difference - like making greener supply chain choices and choosing sustainable partners and suppliers. 
This will continue into a ‘looking to the future’ section where we’ll speak to sustainability experts about what the future looks like for businesses aiming to be more sustainable, and tips on what they can do to stay ahead of the crowd

CONTINUED BELOW
parameterValues.DE:Any other relevant information:
CONTINUED

The last section will look at 5 businesses that are already putting sustainability first, including NatWest. For example, Dell is working with clean ocean company Lonely Whale to fight plastics pollution, and HP’s Instant Ink service combines technology, customer service and environmental responsibility, by delivering replacement ink cartridges to customers when their printer detects low ink levels. We’ll include expert quotes and comment from these companies in here too

parameterValues.DE:Objective:
Make target audience aware of Brittany Ferries’ holiday offerings.

Change perceptions of Brittany Ferries being solely a ferry service and increase awareness of great destination holiday packages in France and Spain. 

Push travel in shoulder months / outside of school holidays.

Encourage early bookings to buck the general trend of late bookings - message being that it’s worth committing early to get your pick of the best options.

Reassure people that although there is uncertainty with Brexit, they can stay safe in the knowledge that Brittany Ferries will do everything we can to ensure the travel remains as easy as possible.

Destination the most important element.

Encourage people to rethink destinations they thought they knew well – suggesting hidden gems and activities.

Highlight the niches where Brittany Ferries can add expertise and value, such as golf, motorcycle/car touring, gourmet cruises etc.

Extol the freedom and value of Brittany Ferries’ holiday packages, such as self-catering, self-drive, pet-friendly holidays etc

Discuss the value  of car tours – discovering new sights, all planned for you, just pack the car and drive, enjoying a new adventure, great selection of new tours, freedom to stop as you choose
-	https://www.brittany-ferries.co.uk/holidays/car-motorcycle-tours/spain/amazing-andalucia
-	https://www.brittany-ferries.co.uk/holidays/car-motorcycle-tours/spain/charm-hidden-spain
-	https://www.brittany-ferries.co.uk/holidays/car-motorcycle-tours/france/caves-castles-dordogne
-	https://www.brittany-ferries.co.uk/holidays/car-motorcycle-tours/france/royal-normandy
-	https://www.brittany-ferries.co.uk/holidays/car-motorcycle-tours/spain/pilgrimage-tour

Digital content will be shaped with SEO in mind, eg people are more likely to search with a more specific focus in mind, such as motorcyle touring in Normandy, instead of searching more broadly for Spain & France in the same search.

parameterValues.DE:Prize Details:
The prize is a 5-night ‘The Caves and Castles of the Dordogne’ car or motorcycle tour with Brittany Ferries, including return ferry travel to France for a standard car and 2 passengers from Portsmouth, Poole or Plymouth. Includes a standard 4-berth cabin (on cruise sailings only, subject to availability), and 3 nights at the selected tour hotels, with breakfast. (See https://www.brittany-ferries.co.uk/holidays/car-motorcycle-tours/france/caves-castles-dordogne for full details and itinerary).

Prize can be taken between 1 March and 30 June 2020, or 7 September until 30 November2020, inclusive, subject to availability.   
Prize winners must provide their own transport – car or motorcycle – and must arrange their own travel insurance
parameterValues.DE:Any other relevant information: Document attached for full details of the competiton

OOA.0901.The X best hikes in Spain that aren’t the Camino de Santiago

parameterValues.DE:Objective:
Make target audience aware of Brittany Ferries’ holiday offerings.

Change perceptions of Brittany Ferries being solely a ferry service and increase awareness of great destination holiday packages in France and Spain. 

Push travel in shoulder months / outside of school holidays.

Encourage early bookings to buck the general trend of late bookings - message being that it’s worth committing early to get your pick of the best options.

Reassure people that although there is uncertainty with Brexit, they can stay safe in the knowledge that Brittany Ferries will do everything we can to ensure the travel remains as easy as possible.
Destination the most important element.

Encourage people to rethink destinations they thought they knew well – suggesting hidden gems and activities.

Highlight the niches where Brittany Ferries can add expertise and value, such as golf, motorcycle/car touring, gourmet cruises etc.

Extol the freedom and value of Brittany Ferries’ holiday packages, such as self-catering, self-drive, pet-friendly holidays etc

Discuss the value  of car tours – discovering new sights, all planned for you, just pack the car and drive, enjoying a new adventure, great selection of new tours, freedom to stop as you choose
-	https://www.brittany-ferries.co.uk/holidays/car-motorcycle-tours/spain/amazing-andalucia
-	https://www.brittany-ferries.co.uk/holidays/car-motorcycle-tours/spain/charm-hidden-spain
-	https://www.brittany-ferries.co.uk/holidays/car-motorcycle-tours/france/caves-castles-dordogne
-	https://www.brittany-ferries.co.uk/holidays/car-motorcycle-tours/france/royal-normandy
-	https://www.brittany-ferries.co.uk/holidays/car-motorcycle-tours/spain/pilgrimage-tour

Digital content will be shaped with SEO in mind, eg people are more likely to search with a more specific focus in mind, such as motorcyle touring in Normandy, instead of searching more broadly for Spain & France in the same search.
parameterValues.DE:Call to Action: The offer to be promoted in January is save up to 20% on any Brittany Ferries sail & stay holiday booked by 11 February 2020. CTAs will be updated after 11 Feb with new offer. Advertiser to amended if needed.
